bestBHT.bht: The orderly arrangement in the tomb, with the napkin wrapped separately, signifies the absence of haste and precipitation in Jesus' awakening and rising from the dead. This intentional act of folding the napkin by itself refutes false interpretations and serves as a testimony to Christ laying aside the tokens of death and clothing himself with a blessed and immortal life. The placement of the napkin also indicates that the body was not taken away in a hurry or by thieves, but by either our Lord himself or the angels.

Henry Alford: On the napkin, see ch. xi. 44 and note.
Marvin Vincent: The orderly arrangement of everything in the tomb marks the absence of haste and precipitation in the awakening and rising from the dead.
The absence of haste and precipitation in the awakening and rising from the dead.
John Calvin: When the Evangelist says, that a napkin was wrapped about his head, this refutes the falsehood of the Papists...
But this gross falsehood is intolerable, because it openly contradicts the evangelical history.
Let us be satisfied with this simple view of the matter, that Christ, by laying aside the tokens of death, intended to testify that he had clothed himself with a blessed and immortal life.
Archibald T. Robertson: This napkin for the head was in a separate place."
Rolled up, from 'to wrap in, to roll up.' It was arranged in an orderly fashion. There was no haste."
John Gill: The word σουδαριον, rendered 'napkin', is thought to be originally Latin, and signifies an handkerchief, with which the sweat is wiped off the face."
By going into the sepulchre, Peter observed that this head binder, or napkin, was not lying with the linen clothes, but wrapped together in a place by itself."
It clearly showed that the body was not taken away in a hurry, or by thieves, since everything lay in such order and decency; and which was done, either by our Lord himself, or by the angels.

bhtAttempts.bht: The orderly arrangement of everything in the tomb, including the napkin wrapped separately, signifies the absence of haste and precipitation in Jesus' awakening and rising from the dead. This intentional act of folding the napkin by itself refutes false interpretations and serves as a testimony to Christ laying aside the tokens of death and clothing himself with a blessed and immortal life. The placement of the napkin also indicates that the body was not taken away in a hurry or by thieves, but by either our Lord himself or the angels.

The orderly arrangement in the tomb, with the napkin wrapped separately, shows that Jesus' resurrection was not hasty or rushed. Instead, it was a deliberate act, proclaiming his victorious rising from the dead. The placement of the napkin by itself refutes false beliefs and signifies that Jesus had clothed himself with a blessed and immortal life. This order and decency in the tomb reveal that the body was not taken away hastily or by thieves, but by either Jesus himself or the angels.

The orderly arrangement in the tomb, with the napkin wrapped separately, shows that Jesus' resurrection was not hasty or rushed. The napkin was carefully folded, indicating a deliberate and purposeful awakening and rising from the dead. Its placement also refutes false interpretations and serves as a testimony to Jesus laying aside the tokens of death and clothing himself with a blessed and immortal life. The orderliness in the tomb suggests that the body was not taken away hastily or by thieves, but by either Jesus himself or the angels.

The orderly arrangement in the tomb, with the napkin wrapped separately, signifies the absence of haste and precipitation in Jesus' awakening and rising from the dead. This intentional act of folding the napkin by itself refutes false interpretations and serves as a testimony to Christ laying aside the tokens of death and clothing himself with a blessed and immortal life. The placement of the napkin also indicates that the body was not taken away in a hurry or by thieves, but by either our Lord himself or the angels.

The orderly arrangement of everything in the tomb, including the separate wrapping of the napkin, suggests that Jesus' resurrection was not hasty or rushed. By carefully folding the napkin and placing it by itself, Jesus indicates his deliberate and purposeful awakening and rising from the dead. This action serves as a testimony to his victory over death and his assumption of a blessed and immortal life. The ordered state of the tomb also implies that the body was not taken away hastily or by thieves, but by Jesus himself or the angels.
